__init__(curvature=1, directix_angle=0, apex_distance=1, **kwargs)¶

Constructor for the ConicalMirror class. For details of convention of conical parameter, see ConicalMirror class doc.

Parameters:

  • curvature (float) – curvature (1/Rc) of the directric circle passing through the origin point in m-1

  • directix_angle (float) – inclination angle of the directrix circle plane with respect to the YOZ plane in rad

  • apex_distance (float) – distance from apex to the origin point

  • kwargs – See OpticalElement doc for parameters

add_circular_stop(radius, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0)¶

Add a circular stop to the aperture. Note a circular stop is of kind “Ellipse”

Parameters:

  • radius (float) – The radius of the circular stop.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

add_elliptical_stop(x_axis, y_axis, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Add an elliptical stop to the aperture.

Parameters:

  • x_axis (float) – The length of the major axis of the ellipse.

  • y_axis (float) – The length of the minor axis of the ellipse.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

add_polygonal_stop(num_sides, vertex_array, opacity=0)¶

Add a polygonal stop to the aperture.

Parameters:

  • num_sides (int) – The number of sides of the polygon.

  • vertex_array (array-like) – The vertices of the polygon.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

add_rectangular_stop(x_width, y_width, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Add a rectangular region to the aperture. X axis is along the length of the optical element.

Parameters:

  • x_width (float) – Width of the rectangular region.

  • y_width (float) – Height of the rectangular region.

  • opacity (float) – Opacity of the rectangular stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – X-coordinate of the center of the rectangular stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – Y-coordinate of the center of the rectangular stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – Rotation angle of the rectangular stop in radians. Default is 0.

draw_aperture(max_vertex=8)¶

Draw all the sub region of the aperture, the ones that are absorbing inside are filled with black.

Parameters:

max_vertex (int) – The maximum number of vertices to look up in memory for polygons. Default is 8.

dump_properties(verbose=1)¶

Prints all stored optix parameters

enumerate_stops(max_vertex=8)¶

Any Element based on a Surface class has an ApertureStop member, which is composed of an array of superimposed stopping Region Regions or Stops;

  • Each Region is a simply connected domain, which can be either a Polygon or an Ellipse.

    Mind that no check is made on the simply connected character of a polygon when created

  • Each region defines the opacity of its inside area and imposes it over all underlying regions. *

  • It doesn’t define the opacity of its outside area unless it is the bottom element of the stack. *

    • if the region Opacity=true, the optical transmittance is 0 inside the region

    • if the region Opacity=false, the optical transmittance is 1. inside the region

  • The opacity of the intersection of all outside areas of all region is the opposite of the opacity of the

    bottom region (first define in the stack)

In other words, the first stop defines an opacity in all space. Adding an opaque Region obstructs the transmission under the region area, but does not change the outside while adding a transparent Region opens an aperture though all the stacked stops &nd still does not change the outside

  • The logical stack should define reducing region sizes from bottom to top. This is intended to allow rounding

    of squared apertures and stops.

All functions of the Aperture API are returning a size_t value. A negative return value, actually -1, means an error occurred and the GetOptiXLastError can be checked for a reason.

Parameters:

max_vertex (int) – number of expected vertexes to be looked up in memory, 8 for a rectangle. Must be even. Default: 8

Returns:

Dictionnary containing the regions describing the aperture and their parameters

Return type:

dict

export_beam_mcpl(reference_frame)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, exports a MCPL (see https://mctools.github.io/mcpl/) in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame (see doc of OpticalElement.get_impacts)

Parameters:

reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see OpticalElement.get_impacts

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

Sets all the optical element parameters using a preexisting optix object which handle is passed as element_id.

Parameters:

  • element_id (wintypes.INT) – Handle of the preexisting optix objects

  • print_all (bool) – set to true to print all values of parameters

Returns:

None

Get the activity state of the aperture, i.e. whether the aperture is used for propagation or not.

Returns:

The activity state of the aperture.

Return type:

bool

get_diagram(distance_from_oe=0, show_first_rays=False)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, returns a (X, Y, dX, dY, Lambda) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray

Parameters:

  • distance_from_oe (str) – distance from the element at which to draw the spot diagram in m

  • show_first_rays (bool) – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

Returns:

pandas.Dataframe containing all rays intercept on the optics surface

get_elliptical_stop_parameters(index)¶

Get the parameters of an elliptical stop in the aperture.

Parameters:

index (int) – The index of the elliptical stop, see enumerate_stops.

Returns:

A tuple containing the parameters of the elliptical stop : boolean=1 if parameters have been successfully retrieved + parameters in the order defined in add_elliptical_stop

Return type:

tuple

get_exit_frame(verbose=0, degrees=True)¶

Returns the beam frame orientation and position after the given element in the absolute frame

This method return an array of four vectors of size 3, in the location pointed by frame_vectors. They are respectively and in this order, the unit vectors in X, Y, and Z, followed by the position of the frame origin in the absolute frame, where Z in normal to the surface at it center, Y tangent to the length of the surface, X tangent to the width of the surface. The PyOptix reference frame (X,Y,Z) translates in the SOLEIL frame as (-X, Z, S), ie the SOLEIL frame (S, X, Z) has a PyOptix matrix of [[0,0,1], [-1,0,0], [0,1,0]]

Returns:

dictionnary containing the coordinate of each local axis of the exit frame in the reference frame, a 3 float array describing its center and the pitch, roll and yaw angle of the surface frame relative to rotations around X, Y and Z respectively

Return type:

dict

get_impacts(reference_frame='surface_frame', show_first_rays=False)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, returns a (X, Y, Z, dX, dY, dZ, Lambda, Intensity) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame either :

  • “general_frame” : Absolute laboratory frame

  • “local_absolute_frame” : Absolute frame with origin on the surface

  • “aligned_local_frame” : Local frame, with origin on the surface, axe OZ is along the chief ray and OY is in the deviation plane of the last preceding reflective element. Transmissive elements do not change the AlignedLocalFrame

  • “surface_frame” : Local frame used to describe a surface. Origin is at surface intercept with the chief ray. Oz is along the surface normal (at origin). OX is the tangential axis for reflective elements.

Method to be used for computing footprints on a mirror.

Parameters:

  • reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see above

  • show_first_rays (bool) – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

Returns:

pandas.Dataframe containing all rays intercept on the optics surface

get_local_frame(verbose=0, degrees=True)¶

Returns the surface frame orientation and position of the given element in the absolute frame

This method return an array of four vectors of size 3, in the location pointed by frame_vectors. They are respectively and in this order, the unit vectors in X, Y, and Z, followed by the position of the frame origin in the absolute frame, where Z in normal to the surface at it center, Y tangent to the length of the surface, X tangent to the width of the surface. The PyOptix reference frame (X,Y,Z) translates in the SOLEIL frame as (-X, Z, S), ie the SOLEIL frame (S, X, Z) has a PyOptix matrix of [[0,0,1], [-1,0,0], [0,1,0]]

Returns:

dictionnary containing the coordinate of each local axis of the surface in the reference frame, a 3 float array describing its center and the pitch, roll and yaw angle of the surface frame relative to rotations around X, Y and Z respectively

Return type:

dict

get_polygon_parameters(index, array_width)¶

  • array_width (int) – The width of the array storing the stops.

A tuple containing the parameters of the polygonal stop and the opacity of the polygon.

Insert a circular stop at the specified index in the aperture.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the circular stop.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • x_axis (float) – The length of the major axis of the ellipse.

  • y_axis (float) – The length of the minor axis of the ellipse.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • y_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the y-axis.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the circular stop.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • x_axis (float) – The length of the major axis of the ellipse.

  • y_axis (float) – The length of the minor axis of the ellipse.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • x_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the x-axis.

  • y_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the y-axis.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

Set the activity state of the aperture, i.e. whether the aperture is used for propagation or not.

Parameters:

active (bool) – The activity state of the aperture. Default is True.

set_recording(recording_mode='output')¶

Sets the recording mode for the spot diagram associated with the element. Recording mode can be “output” (records rays affected by the element), “input” (records ray just before reaching the element), “not_recording” (does not record the rays).

Parameters:

recording_mode (str) – When to record the rays in reference to the element (see above)

Returns:

None

set_transmissive(is_transmissive)¶

Sets an optical element as transmissive or reflective depending on the value of is_transmissive. Only authorized for gratings

is_transmissive (bool) – if True, makes the optical element transmissive, if False, reflective

None

Return type:

Nonetype

show_diagram(distance_from_oe=0, map_xy=False, light_xy=False, light_xxp=False, light_yyp=False, show_first_rays=False, display='all', show_spd=True, **kwargs)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, displays X vs Y, X’ vs X and Y’ vs Y scatter plots at a distance distance_from_oe from the element. For quick display, light_xy, light_xxp and light_yyp can be set to True. For more realistic rendering, map_xy can be set to True.

Parameters:

  • distance_from_oe (str) – distance from the element at which to draw the spot diagram in m

  • map_xy (bool) – set to True for hexagonal pixel rendering of X vs Y diagram

  • light_xy (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of X vs Y scatter plot

  • light_xxp (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of X’ vs X scatter plot

  • light_yyp (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of Y’ vs Y scatter plot

  • show_first_rays – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

  • display (str) – Indicates which representation is to be shown, can be “xy”, “xy, xxp”… or “all”

  • kwargs – See pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd doc for additional parameters

Returns:

tuple of (spd_data, handle(s) of the figures)

Return type:

tuple

show_impacts(reference_frame='local_absolute_frame', plots=None, **kwargs)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, shows by default the (X,Y) and (X,Z) cross sections of the (X, Y, Z, dX, dY, dZ, Lambda, Intensity) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame either :

  • “general_frame” : Absolute laboratory frame

  • “local_absolute_frame” : Absolute frame with origin on the surface

  • “aligned_local_frame” : Local frame, with origin on the surface, axe OZ is along the chief ray and OY is in the deviation plane of the last preceding reflective element. Transmissive elements do not change the AlignedLocalFrame

  • “surface_frame” : Local frame used to describe a surface. Origin is at surface intercept with the chief ray. Oz is along the surface normal (at origin). OX is the tangential axis for reflective elements.

Method to be used for computing footprints on a mirror.

Parameters:

  • plots (list of tuple) – Plots to be displayed. Default is [(“X”, “Y”), (“X”, “Z”)]

  • nrays (int) – number of expected rays (default: source_oe.nrays). Only use if generate is called multiple times.

  • reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see above

  • kwargs – See pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd doc for additional parameters

Returns:

tuple of (spd_data, handle(s) of the figures)

Return type:

tuple

class pyoptix.classes.CylindricalFilm(*args, **kw)¶

Class for cylindrical films. Inherits CylindricalMirror

Methods:

__init__(**kwargs)

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, shows by default the (X,Y) and (X,Z) cross sections of the (X, Y, Z, dX, dY, dZ, Lambda, Intensity) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame either :
__init__(**kwargs)¶

Constructor of the CylindricalFilm class.

Parameters:

kwargs – See CylindricalMirror doc for the parameters

add_circular_stop(radius, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0)¶

Add a circular stop to the aperture. Note a circular stop is of kind “Ellipse”

Parameters:

  • radius (float) – The radius of the circular stop.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

add_elliptical_stop(x_axis, y_axis, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Add an elliptical stop to the aperture.

Parameters:

  • x_axis (float) – The length of the major axis of the ellipse.

  • y_axis (float) – The length of the minor axis of the ellipse.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

add_polygonal_stop(num_sides, vertex_array, opacity=0)¶

Add a polygonal stop to the aperture.

Parameters:

  • num_sides (int) – The number of sides of the polygon.

  • vertex_array (array-like) – The vertices of the polygon.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

add_rectangular_stop(x_width, y_width, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Add a rectangular region to the aperture. X axis is along the length of the optical element.

Parameters:

  • x_width (float) – Width of the rectangular region.

  • y_width (float) – Height of the rectangular region.

  • opacity (float) – Opacity of the rectangular stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – X-coordinate of the center of the rectangular stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – Y-coordinate of the center of the rectangular stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – Rotation angle of the rectangular stop in radians. Default is 0.

draw_aperture(max_vertex=8)¶

Draw all the sub region of the aperture, the ones that are absorbing inside are filled with black.

Parameters:

max_vertex (int) – The maximum number of vertices to look up in memory for polygons. Default is 8.

dump_properties(verbose=1)¶

Prints all stored optix parameters

enumerate_stops(max_vertex=8)¶

Any Element based on a Surface class has an ApertureStop member, which is composed of an array of superimposed stopping Region Regions or Stops;

  • Each Region is a simply connected domain, which can be either a Polygon or an Ellipse.

    Mind that no check is made on the simply connected character of a polygon when created

  • Each region defines the opacity of its inside area and imposes it over all underlying regions. *

  • It doesn’t define the opacity of its outside area unless it is the bottom element of the stack. *

    • if the region Opacity=true, the optical transmittance is 0 inside the region

    • if the region Opacity=false, the optical transmittance is 1. inside the region

  • The opacity of the intersection of all outside areas of all region is the opposite of the opacity of the

    bottom region (first define in the stack)

In other words, the first stop defines an opacity in all space. Adding an opaque Region obstructs the transmission under the region area, but does not change the outside while adding a transparent Region opens an aperture though all the stacked stops &nd still does not change the outside

  • The logical stack should define reducing region sizes from bottom to top. This is intended to allow rounding

    of squared apertures and stops.

All functions of the Aperture API are returning a size_t value. A negative return value, actually -1, means an error occurred and the GetOptiXLastError can be checked for a reason.

Parameters:

max_vertex (int) – number of expected vertexes to be looked up in memory, 8 for a rectangle. Must be even. Default: 8

Returns:

Dictionnary containing the regions describing the aperture and their parameters

Return type:

dict

export_beam_mcpl(reference_frame)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, exports a MCPL (see https://mctools.github.io/mcpl/) in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame (see doc of OpticalElement.get_impacts)

Parameters:

reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see OpticalElement.get_impacts

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

from_element_id(element_id, print_all=False)¶

Sets all the optical element parameters using a preexisting optix object which handle is passed as element_id.

Parameters:

  • element_id (wintypes.INT) – Handle of the preexisting optix objects

  • print_all (bool) – set to true to print all values of parameters

Returns:

None

get_aperture_activity()¶

Get the activity state of the aperture, i.e. whether the aperture is used for propagation or not.

Returns:

The activity state of the aperture.

Return type:

bool

get_diagram(distance_from_oe=0, show_first_rays=False)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, returns a (X, Y, dX, dY, Lambda) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray

Parameters:

  • distance_from_oe (str) – distance from the element at which to draw the spot diagram in m

  • show_first_rays (bool) – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

Returns:

pandas.Dataframe containing all rays intercept on the optics surface

get_elliptical_stop_parameters(index)¶

Get the parameters of an elliptical stop in the aperture.

Parameters:

index (int) – The index of the elliptical stop, see enumerate_stops.

Returns:

A tuple containing the parameters of the elliptical stop : boolean=1 if parameters have been successfully retrieved + parameters in the order defined in add_elliptical_stop

Return type:

tuple

get_exit_frame(verbose=0, degrees=True)¶

Returns the beam frame orientation and position after the given element in the absolute frame

This method return an array of four vectors of size 3, in the location pointed by frame_vectors. They are respectively and in this order, the unit vectors in X, Y, and Z, followed by the position of the frame origin in the absolute frame, where Z in normal to the surface at it center, Y tangent to the length of the surface, X tangent to the width of the surface. The PyOptix reference frame (X,Y,Z) translates in the SOLEIL frame as (-X, Z, S), ie the SOLEIL frame (S, X, Z) has a PyOptix matrix of [[0,0,1], [-1,0,0], [0,1,0]]

Returns:

dictionnary containing the coordinate of each local axis of the exit frame in the reference frame, a 3 float array describing its center and the pitch, roll and yaw angle of the surface frame relative to rotations around X, Y and Z respectively

Return type:

dict

get_impacts(reference_frame='surface_frame', show_first_rays=False)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, returns a (X, Y, Z, dX, dY, dZ, Lambda, Intensity) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame either :

  • “general_frame” : Absolute laboratory frame

  • “local_absolute_frame” : Absolute frame with origin on the surface

  • “aligned_local_frame” : Local frame, with origin on the surface, axe OZ is along the chief ray and OY is in the deviation plane of the last preceding reflective element. Transmissive elements do not change the AlignedLocalFrame

  • “surface_frame” : Local frame used to describe a surface. Origin is at surface intercept with the chief ray. Oz is along the surface normal (at origin). OX is the tangential axis for reflective elements.

Method to be used for computing footprints on a mirror.

Parameters:

  • reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see above

  • show_first_rays (bool) – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

Returns:

pandas.Dataframe containing all rays intercept on the optics surface

get_local_frame(verbose=0, degrees=True)¶

Returns the surface frame orientation and position of the given element in the absolute frame

This method return an array of four vectors of size 3, in the location pointed by frame_vectors. They are respectively and in this order, the unit vectors in X, Y, and Z, followed by the position of the frame origin in the absolute frame, where Z in normal to the surface at it center, Y tangent to the length of the surface, X tangent to the width of the surface. The PyOptix reference frame (X,Y,Z) translates in the SOLEIL frame as (-X, Z, S), ie the SOLEIL frame (S, X, Z) has a PyOptix matrix of [[0,0,1], [-1,0,0], [0,1,0]]

Returns:

dictionnary containing the coordinate of each local axis of the surface in the reference frame, a 3 float array describing its center and the pitch, roll and yaw angle of the surface frame relative to rotations around X, Y and Z respectively

Return type:

dict

get_polygon_parameters(index, array_width)¶

Get the parameters of a polygonal stop in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the polygonal stop in the list of apertures, see enumerate_stops.

  • array_width (int) – The width of the array storing the stops.

Returns:

A tuple containing the parameters of the polygonal stop and the opacity of the polygon.

Return type:

tuple

get_transmissive()¶

Returns True if optical element is transmissive, False if reflective.

Returns:

True if optical element is transmissive, False if reflective

Return type:

bool

insert_circular_stop(index, radius, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0)¶

Insert a circular stop at the specified index in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index at which the circular stop should be inserted.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the circular stop.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

insert_elliptical_stop(index, x_axis, y_axis, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Insert an elliptical stop at the specified index in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index at which the elliptical stop should be inserted, see enumerate_stops.

  • x_axis (float) – The length of the major axis of the ellipse.

  • y_axis (float) – The length of the minor axis of the ellipse.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

insert_polygonal_stop(index, num_sides, vertex_array, opacity=0)¶

Insert a polygonal stop at the specified index in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index at which the polygonal stop should be inserted. See enumerate.stops.

  • num_sides (int) – The number of sides of the polygon.

  • vertex_array (array-like) – The vertices of the polygon.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

insert_rectangular_stop(index, x_width, y_width, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Insert a rectangular stop at the specified index in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index at which the rectangular stop should be inserted, see enumerate_stops.

  • x_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the x-axis.

  • y_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the y-axis.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

replace_stop_by_circle(index, radius, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0)¶

Replace a stop in the aperture with a circular stop.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the stop to be replaced, see enumerate_stops.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the circular stop.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

replace_stop_by_ellipse(index, x_axis, y_axis, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Replace a stop in the aperture with an elliptical stop.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the stop to be replaced, see enumerate_stops.

  • x_axis (float) – The length of the major axis of the ellipse.

  • y_axis (float) – The length of the minor axis of the ellipse.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

replace_stop_by_polygon(index, num_sides, vertex_array, opacity=0)¶

Replace a stop in the aperture with a polygonal stop.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the stop to be replaced, see enumerate_stops.

  • num_sides (int) – The number of sides of the polygon.

  • vertex_array (array-like) – The vertices of the polygon.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

replace_stop_by_rectangle(index, x_width, y_width, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Replace a stop in the aperture with a rectangular stop.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the stop to be replaced, see enumerate_stops.

  • x_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the x-axis.

  • y_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the y-axis.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

set_aperture_activity(active=True)¶

Set the activity state of the aperture, i.e. whether the aperture is used for propagation or not.

Parameters:

active (bool) – The activity state of the aperture. Default is True.

set_recording(recording_mode='output')¶

Sets the recording mode for the spot diagram associated with the element. Recording mode can be “output” (records rays affected by the element), “input” (records ray just before reaching the element), “not_recording” (does not record the rays).

Parameters:

recording_mode (str) – When to record the rays in reference to the element (see above)

Returns:

None

set_transmissive(is_transmissive)¶

Sets an optical element as transmissive or reflective depending on the value of is_transmissive. Only authorized for gratings

Parameters:

is_transmissive (bool) – if True, makes the optical element transmissive, if False, reflective

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

show_diagram(distance_from_oe=0, map_xy=False, light_xy=False, light_xxp=False, light_yyp=False, show_first_rays=False, display='all', show_spd=True, **kwargs)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, displays X vs Y, X’ vs X and Y’ vs Y scatter plots at a distance distance_from_oe from the element. For quick display, light_xy, light_xxp and light_yyp can be set to True. For more realistic rendering, map_xy can be set to True.

Parameters:

  • distance_from_oe (str) – distance from the element at which to draw the spot diagram in m

  • map_xy (bool) – set to True for hexagonal pixel rendering of X vs Y diagram

  • light_xy (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of X vs Y scatter plot

  • light_xxp (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of X’ vs X scatter plot

  • light_yyp (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of Y’ vs Y scatter plot

  • show_first_rays – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

  • display (str) – Indicates which representation is to be shown, can be “xy”, “xy, xxp”… or “all”

  • kwargs – See pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd doc for additional parameters

Returns:

tuple of (spd_data, handle(s) of the figures)

Return type:

tuple

show_impacts(reference_frame='local_absolute_frame', plots=None, **kwargs)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, shows by default the (X,Y) and (X,Z) cross sections of the (X, Y, Z, dX, dY, dZ, Lambda, Intensity) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame either :

  • “general_frame” : Absolute laboratory frame

  • “local_absolute_frame” : Absolute frame with origin on the surface

  • “aligned_local_frame” : Local frame, with origin on the surface, axe OZ is along the chief ray and OY is in the deviation plane of the last preceding reflective element. Transmissive elements do not change the AlignedLocalFrame

  • “surface_frame” : Local frame used to describe a surface. Origin is at surface intercept with the chief ray. Oz is along the surface normal (at origin). OX is the tangential axis for reflective elements.

Method to be used for computing footprints on a mirror.

Parameters:

  • plots (list of tuple) – Plots to be displayed. Default is [(“X”, “Y”), (“X”, “Z”)]

  • nrays (int) – number of expected rays (default: source_oe.nrays). Only use if generate is called multiple times.

  • reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see above

  • kwargs – See pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd doc for additional parameters

Returns:

tuple of (spd_data, handle(s) of the figures)

Return type:

tuple

class pyoptix.classes.CylindricalHoloGrating(*args, **kw)¶

Class for cylindrical holographic gratings. Inherits CylindricalMirror and PlaneHoloGrating

Methods:

Constructor of the CylindricalHoloGrating class.

from_solemio(inverse_dist1, inverse_dist2, ...)

get_angles([degree])

Returns the incidence angle (alpha), exit angle (beta) and half deviation angle (theta) of an aligned grating :param degree: if True angles are returned in degrees :type degree: bool :return: dictionnary containing alpha, beta and theta :rtype: dict

Method for calculating the hologram parameters in the convention used by SOLEMIO.

get_tpmm(point_m)

Method for calculating the local line density of an hologram at a given point which coordinates are given in point_m.

get_transmissive()

Returns True if optical element is transmissive, False if reflective.

get_vls_law(x_span, order[, return_tpm, ...])

Method for computing the Varied Line Space law of the hologram along its central axis (azimuth=0).

Sets the recording mode for the spot diagram associated with the element.

Sets an optical element as transmissive or reflective depending on the value of is_transmissive.

show_diagram([distance_from_oe, map_xy, ...])

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, displays X vs Y, X' vs X and Y' vs Y scatter plots at a distance distance_from_oe from the element.

show_impacts([reference_frame, plots])

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, shows by default the (X,Y) and (X,Z) cross sections of the (X, Y, Z, dX, dY, dZ, Lambda, Intensity) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame either :

show_vls_law(x_span, order[, sample_number])

Displays the local line densities computed by pyoptix.PlaneHoloGrating.get_vls_law as well as the fit of those diplaying in legend the coefficients of the polynomial fit.

update_construction_points()

Method to be called for recomputation of the construction points of the hologram.
__init__(**kwargs)¶

Constructor of the CylindricalHoloGrating class.

Parameters:

kwargs – See CylindricalMirror and PlaneHoloGrating doc for the parameters

add_circular_stop(radius, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0)¶

Add a circular stop to the aperture. Note a circular stop is of kind “Ellipse”

Parameters:

  • radius (float) – The radius of the circular stop.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

add_elliptical_stop(x_axis, y_axis, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Add an elliptical stop to the aperture.

Parameters:

  • x_axis (float) – The length of the major axis of the ellipse.

  • y_axis (float) – The length of the minor axis of the ellipse.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

add_polygonal_stop(num_sides, vertex_array, opacity=0)¶

Add a polygonal stop to the aperture.

Parameters:

  • num_sides (int) – The number of sides of the polygon.

  • vertex_array (array-like) – The vertices of the polygon.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

add_rectangular_stop(x_width, y_width, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Add a rectangular region to the aperture. X axis is along the length of the optical element.

Parameters:

  • x_width (float) – Width of the rectangular region.

  • y_width (float) – Height of the rectangular region.

  • opacity (float) – Opacity of the rectangular stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – X-coordinate of the center of the rectangular stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – Y-coordinate of the center of the rectangular stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – Rotation angle of the rectangular stop in radians. Default is 0.

draw_aperture(max_vertex=8)¶

Draw all the sub region of the aperture, the ones that are absorbing inside are filled with black.

Parameters:

max_vertex (int) – The maximum number of vertices to look up in memory for polygons. Default is 8.

dump_properties(verbose=1)¶

Prints all stored optix parameters

enumerate_stops(max_vertex=8)¶

Any Element based on a Surface class has an ApertureStop member, which is composed of an array of superimposed stopping Region Regions or Stops;

  • Each Region is a simply connected domain, which can be either a Polygon or an Ellipse.

    Mind that no check is made on the simply connected character of a polygon when created

  • Each region defines the opacity of its inside area and imposes it over all underlying regions. *

  • It doesn’t define the opacity of its outside area unless it is the bottom element of the stack. *

    • if the region Opacity=true, the optical transmittance is 0 inside the region

    • if the region Opacity=false, the optical transmittance is 1. inside the region

  • The opacity of the intersection of all outside areas of all region is the opposite of the opacity of the

    bottom region (first define in the stack)

In other words, the first stop defines an opacity in all space. Adding an opaque Region obstructs the transmission under the region area, but does not change the outside while adding a transparent Region opens an aperture though all the stacked stops &nd still does not change the outside

  • The logical stack should define reducing region sizes from bottom to top. This is intended to allow rounding

    of squared apertures and stops.

All functions of the Aperture API are returning a size_t value. A negative return value, actually -1, means an error occurred and the GetOptiXLastError can be checked for a reason.

Parameters:

max_vertex (int) – number of expected vertexes to be looked up in memory, 8 for a rectangle. Must be even. Default: 8

Returns:

Dictionnary containing the regions describing the aperture and their parameters

Return type:

dict

export_beam_mcpl(reference_frame)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, exports a MCPL (see https://mctools.github.io/mcpl/) in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame (see doc of OpticalElement.get_impacts)

Parameters:

reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see OpticalElement.get_impacts

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

from_element_id(element_id, print_all=False)¶

Sets all the optical element parameters using a preexisting optix object which handle is passed as element_id.

Parameters:

  • element_id (wintypes.INT) – Handle of the preexisting optix objects

  • print_all (bool) – set to true to print all values of parameters

Returns:

None

from_horiba(dist1, dist2, angle1, angle2, lamda=None)¶

Definition of the hologram using the Horiba (Jobin-Yvon) convention where:

Parameters:

  • dist1 (float) – distance between grating and point of construction 1

  • dist2 (float) – distance between grating and point of construction 2

  • angle1 (float) – angle (spherical) between normal and axis from grating to point of construction 1

  • angle2 (float) – angle (spherical) between normal and axis from grating to point of construction 2

  • lamda (float) – wavelength used for recording the hologram

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

from_solemio(inverse_dist1, inverse_dist2, cos1, dcos, lamda=None)¶

Definition of the hologram using the SOLEMIO convention where:

Parameters:

  • inverse_dist1 (float) – inverse of the distance between grating and point of construction 1

  • inverse_dist2 (float) – inverse of the distance between grating and point of construction 2

  • cos1 (float) – cosine of the grazing angle (elevation) from grating to point of construction 1

  • dcos (float) – difference between cosines of the grazing angle to points of construction

  • lamda (float) – wavelength used for recording the hologram

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

get_angles(degree=True)¶

Returns the incidence angle (alpha), exit angle (beta) and half deviation angle (theta) of an aligned grating :param degree: if True angles are returned in degrees :type degree: bool :return: dictionnary containing alpha, beta and theta :rtype: dict

get_aperture_activity()¶

Get the activity state of the aperture, i.e. whether the aperture is used for propagation or not.

Returns:

The activity state of the aperture.

Return type:

bool

get_diagram(distance_from_oe=0, show_first_rays=False)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, returns a (X, Y, dX, dY, Lambda) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray

Parameters:

  • distance_from_oe (str) – distance from the element at which to draw the spot diagram in m

  • show_first_rays (bool) – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

Returns:

pandas.Dataframe containing all rays intercept on the optics surface

get_elliptical_stop_parameters(index)¶

Get the parameters of an elliptical stop in the aperture.

Parameters:

index (int) – The index of the elliptical stop, see enumerate_stops.

Returns:

A tuple containing the parameters of the elliptical stop : boolean=1 if parameters have been successfully retrieved + parameters in the order defined in add_elliptical_stop

Return type:

tuple

get_exit_frame(verbose=0, degrees=True)¶

Returns the beam frame orientation and position after the given element in the absolute frame

This method return an array of four vectors of size 3, in the location pointed by frame_vectors. They are respectively and in this order, the unit vectors in X, Y, and Z, followed by the position of the frame origin in the absolute frame, where Z in normal to the surface at it center, Y tangent to the length of the surface, X tangent to the width of the surface. The PyOptix reference frame (X,Y,Z) translates in the SOLEIL frame as (-X, Z, S), ie the SOLEIL frame (S, X, Z) has a PyOptix matrix of [[0,0,1], [-1,0,0], [0,1,0]]

Returns:

dictionnary containing the coordinate of each local axis of the exit frame in the reference frame, a 3 float array describing its center and the pitch, roll and yaw angle of the surface frame relative to rotations around X, Y and Z respectively

Return type:

dict

get_horiba_coords()¶

Method for calculating the hologram parameters in the convention used by Horiba (Jobin Yvon).

Returns:

(Coordinates of point 1, coordinates of point 2 , recording wavelength)

Return type:

tuple

get_impacts(reference_frame='surface_frame', show_first_rays=False)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, returns a (X, Y, Z, dX, dY, dZ, Lambda, Intensity) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame either :

  • “general_frame” : Absolute laboratory frame

  • “local_absolute_frame” : Absolute frame with origin on the surface

  • “aligned_local_frame” : Local frame, with origin on the surface, axe OZ is along the chief ray and OY is in the deviation plane of the last preceding reflective element. Transmissive elements do not change the AlignedLocalFrame

  • “surface_frame” : Local frame used to describe a surface. Origin is at surface intercept with the chief ray. Oz is along the surface normal (at origin). OX is the tangential axis for reflective elements.

Method to be used for computing footprints on a mirror.

Parameters:

  • reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see above

  • show_first_rays (bool) – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

Returns:

pandas.Dataframe containing all rays intercept on the optics surface

get_local_frame(verbose=0, degrees=True)¶

Returns the surface frame orientation and position of the given element in the absolute frame

This method return an array of four vectors of size 3, in the location pointed by frame_vectors. They are respectively and in this order, the unit vectors in X, Y, and Z, followed by the position of the frame origin in the absolute frame, where Z in normal to the surface at it center, Y tangent to the length of the surface, X tangent to the width of the surface. The PyOptix reference frame (X,Y,Z) translates in the SOLEIL frame as (-X, Z, S), ie the SOLEIL frame (S, X, Z) has a PyOptix matrix of [[0,0,1], [-1,0,0], [0,1,0]]

Returns:

dictionnary containing the coordinate of each local axis of the surface in the reference frame, a 3 float array describing its center and the pitch, roll and yaw angle of the surface frame relative to rotations around X, Y and Z respectively

Return type:

dict

get_polygon_parameters(index, array_width)¶

Get the parameters of a polygonal stop in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the polygonal stop in the list of apertures, see enumerate_stops.

  • array_width (int) – The width of the array storing the stops.

Returns:

A tuple containing the parameters of the polygonal stop and the opacity of the polygon.

Return type:

tuple

Returns:

(Coordinates of point 1, coordinates of point 2 , recording wavelength, line density at center)

Return type:

tuple

get_solemio_coords()¶

Method for calculating the hologram parameters in the convention used by SOLEMIO.

Returns:

(Coordinates of point 1, coordinates of point 2 , recording wavelength)

Return type:

tuple

get_tpmm(point_m)¶

Method for calculating the local line density of an hologram at a given point which coordinates are given in point_m.

Parameters:

point_m (pyoptix.Point) – point where the local line density is computed.

Returns:

line density in m^-1

Return type:

float

get_transmissive()¶

Returns True if optical element is transmissive, False if reflective.

Returns:

True if optical element is transmissive, False if reflective

Return type:

bool

get_vls_law(x_span, order, return_tpm=False, sample_number=20)¶

Method for computing the Varied Line Space law of the hologram along its central axis (azimuth=0). Either returns polynomial coefficient (up to degree ‘order’) or both coefficients and list of local line densities at “sample_number” points evenly space over a range of “x_span” meters.

Parameters:

  • x_span (float) – total range over which to compute the VLS law

  • order (int) – degree of the polynomial to which the VLS law is fitted

  • return_tpm (bool) – if True, local list of line densities are returned in a tuple after fit coefficients

  • sample_number (int) – Number of points along the central axis where local line densities are computed

Returns:

tuple of (array of fit coeffs, list of line densities) or array of fit coeffs)

Return type:

array or tuple

insert_circular_stop(index, radius, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0)¶

Insert a circular stop at the specified index in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index at which the circular stop should be inserted.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the circular stop.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

insert_elliptical_stop(index, x_axis, y_axis, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Insert an elliptical stop at the specified index in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index at which the elliptical stop should be inserted, see enumerate_stops.

  • x_axis (float) – The length of the major axis of the ellipse.

  • y_axis (float) – The length of the minor axis of the ellipse.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

insert_polygonal_stop(index, num_sides, vertex_array, opacity=0)¶

Insert a polygonal stop at the specified index in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index at which the polygonal stop should be inserted. See enumerate.stops.

  • num_sides (int) – The number of sides of the polygon.

  • vertex_array (array-like) – The vertices of the polygon.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

insert_rectangular_stop(index, x_width, y_width, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Insert a rectangular stop at the specified index in the aperture.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index at which the rectangular stop should be inserted, see enumerate_stops.

  • x_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the x-axis.

  • y_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the y-axis.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

replace_stop_by_circle(index, radius, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0)¶

Replace a stop in the aperture with a circular stop.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the stop to be replaced, see enumerate_stops.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the circular stop.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

replace_stop_by_ellipse(index, x_axis, y_axis, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Replace a stop in the aperture with an elliptical stop.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the stop to be replaced, see enumerate_stops.

  • x_axis (float) – The length of the major axis of the ellipse.

  • y_axis (float) – The length of the minor axis of the ellipse.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

replace_stop_by_polygon(index, num_sides, vertex_array, opacity=0)¶

Replace a stop in the aperture with a polygonal stop.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the stop to be replaced, see enumerate_stops.

  • num_sides (int) – The number of sides of the polygon.

  • vertex_array (array-like) – The vertices of the polygon.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

replace_stop_by_rectangle(index, x_width, y_width, opacity=0, x_center=0, y_center=0, angle=0)¶

Replace a stop in the aperture with a rectangular stop.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index of the stop to be replaced, see enumerate_stops.

  • x_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the x-axis.

  • y_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the y-axis.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

set_aperture_activity(active=True)¶

Set the activity state of the aperture, i.e. whether the aperture is used for propagation or not.

Parameters:

active (bool) – The activity state of the aperture. Default is True.

set_recording(recording_mode='output')¶

Sets the recording mode for the spot diagram associated with the element. Recording mode can be “output” (records rays affected by the element), “input” (records ray just before reaching the element), “not_recording” (does not record the rays).

Parameters:

recording_mode (str) – When to record the rays in reference to the element (see above)

Returns:

None

set_transmissive(is_transmissive)¶

Sets an optical element as transmissive or reflective depending on the value of is_transmissive. Only authorized for gratings

Parameters:

is_transmissive (bool) – if True, makes the optical element transmissive, if False, reflective

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

show_diagram(distance_from_oe=0, map_xy=False, light_xy=False, light_xxp=False, light_yyp=False, show_first_rays=False, display='all', show_spd=True, **kwargs)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, displays X vs Y, X’ vs X and Y’ vs Y scatter plots at a distance distance_from_oe from the element. For quick display, light_xy, light_xxp and light_yyp can be set to True. For more realistic rendering, map_xy can be set to True.

Parameters:

  • distance_from_oe (str) – distance from the element at which to draw the spot diagram in m

  • map_xy (bool) – set to True for hexagonal pixel rendering of X vs Y diagram

  • light_xy (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of X vs Y scatter plot

  • light_xxp (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of X’ vs X scatter plot

  • light_yyp (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of Y’ vs Y scatter plot

  • show_first_rays – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

  • display (str) – Indicates which representation is to be shown, can be “xy”, “xy, xxp”… or “all”

  • kwargs – See pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd doc for additional parameters

Returns:

tuple of (spd_data, handle(s) of the figures)

Return type:

tuple

show_impacts(reference_frame='local_absolute_frame', plots=None, **kwargs)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, shows by default the (X,Y) and (X,Z) cross sections of the (X, Y, Z, dX, dY, dZ, Lambda, Intensity) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame either :

  • “general_frame” : Absolute laboratory frame

  • “local_absolute_frame” : Absolute frame with origin on the surface

  • “aligned_local_frame” : Local frame, with origin on the surface, axe OZ is along the chief ray and OY is in the deviation plane of the last preceding reflective element. Transmissive elements do not change the AlignedLocalFrame

  • “surface_frame” : Local frame used to describe a surface. Origin is at surface intercept with the chief ray. Oz is along the surface normal (at origin). OX is the tangential axis for reflective elements.

Method to be used for computing footprints on a mirror.

Parameters:

  • plots (list of tuple) – Plots to be displayed. Default is [(“X”, “Y”), (“X”, “Z”)]

  • nrays (int) – number of expected rays (default: source_oe.nrays). Only use if generate is called multiple times.

  • reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see above

  • kwargs – See pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd doc for additional parameters

Returns:

tuple of (spd_data, handle(s) of the figures)

Return type:

tuple

show_vls_law(x_span, order, sample_number=20)¶

Displays the local line densities computed by pyoptix.PlaneHoloGrating.get_vls_law as well as the fit of those diplaying in legend the coefficients of the polynomial fit.

Parameters:

  • x_span (float) – total range over which to compute the VLS law

  • order (int) – degree of the polynomial to which the VLS law is fitted

  • sample_number (int) – Number of points along the central axis where local line densities are computed

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

update_construction_points()¶

Method to be called for recomputation of the construction points of the hologram. In particular, to be called after any change applied to the hologram related attribute of the object.

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

class pyoptix.classes.CylindricalMirror(*args, **kw)¶

Class for the cylindrical spherical mirrors. Inherits OpticalElement. Inherited by “CylindricalFilm”, “CylindricalHoloGrating” and “CylindricalPoly1DGrating”.

Defines a 1d spherical mirror of radius 1/curvature invariant along an axes at axis_angle from the X axes of the mirror.

Methods:

__init__([curvature, axis_angle])

Constructor for the CylindricalMirror class.
