  • x_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the x-axis.

  • y_width (float) – The width of the rectangular stop along the y-axis.

  • opacity (float) – The opacity of the stop. Default is 0 meaning transparent inside the rectangle, absorbant outside of it.

  • x_center (float) – The x-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • y_center (float) – The y-coordinate of the center of the stop. Default is 0.

  • angle (float) – The rotation angle of the stop in radians. Default is 0.

set_aperture_activity(active=True)¶

Set the activity state of the aperture, i.e. whether the aperture is used for propagation or not.

Parameters:

active (bool) – The activity state of the aperture. Default is True.

set_recording(recording_mode='output')¶

Sets the recording mode for the spot diagram associated with the element. Recording mode can be “output” (records rays affected by the element), “input” (records ray just before reaching the element), “not_recording” (does not record the rays).

Parameters:

recording_mode (str) – When to record the rays in reference to the element (see above)

Returns:

None

set_transmissive(is_transmissive)¶

Sets an optical element as transmissive or reflective depending on the value of is_transmissive. Only authorized for gratings

Parameters:

is_transmissive (bool) – if True, makes the optical element transmissive, if False, reflective

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

show_diagram(distance_from_oe=0, map_xy=False, light_xy=False, light_xxp=False, light_yyp=False, show_first_rays=False, display='all', show_spd=True, **kwargs)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, displays X vs Y, X’ vs X and Y’ vs Y scatter plots at a distance distance_from_oe from the element. For quick display, light_xy, light_xxp and light_yyp can be set to True. For more realistic rendering, map_xy can be set to True.

Parameters:

  • distance_from_oe (str) – distance from the element at which to draw the spot diagram in m

  • map_xy (bool) – set to True for hexagonal pixel rendering of X vs Y diagram

  • light_xy (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of X vs Y scatter plot

  • light_xxp (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of X’ vs X scatter plot

  • light_yyp (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of Y’ vs Y scatter plot

  • show_first_rays – set to True for a table display of the parameter of the first rays in diagram

  • display (str) – Indicates which representation is to be shown, can be “xy”, “xy, xxp”… or “all”

  • kwargs – See pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd doc for additional parameters

Returns:

tuple of (spd_data, handle(s) of the figures)

Return type:

tuple

show_impacts(reference_frame='local_absolute_frame', plots=None, **kwargs)¶

If recording_mode is set to any other value than RecordingMode.recording_none, shows by default the (X,Y) and (X,Z) cross sections of the (X, Y, Z, dX, dY, dZ, Lambda, Intensity) pandas dataframe where each row is a computed ray in the frame of reference given in parameter reference_frame either :

  • “general_frame” : Absolute laboratory frame

  • “local_absolute_frame” : Absolute frame with origin on the surface

  • “aligned_local_frame” : Local frame, with origin on the surface, axe OZ is along the chief ray and OY is in the deviation plane of the last preceding reflective element. Transmissive elements do not change the AlignedLocalFrame

  • “surface_frame” : Local frame used to describe a surface. Origin is at surface intercept with the chief ray. Oz is along the surface normal (at origin). OX is the tangential axis for reflective elements.

Method to be used for computing footprints on a mirror.

Parameters:

  • plots (list of tuple) – Plots to be displayed. Default is [(“X”, “Y”), (“X”, “Z”)]

  • nrays (int) – number of expected rays (default: source_oe.nrays). Only use if generate is called multiple times.

  • reference_frame (str) – reference frame for coordinates see above

  • kwargs – See pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd doc for additional parameters

Returns:

tuple of (spd_data, handle(s) of the figures)

Return type:

tuple

pyoptix.classes.align_as_pseudo_petersen(grating: ~pyoptix.classes.Grating, mirror: ~pyoptix.classes.PlaneMirror, lambda_align: float, condition: str = 'cff', condition_value=<function <lambda>>, verbose: int = 0, dz: float = 0.015, offset_mirror_center: bool = False, return_parameters: bool = False)¶

The mirror associated to the grating turns around a point located at (0,-dz/2) from the grating center and is at an angle compensating the grating deviation. In the grating frame of reference, the mirror is therefore tangent to the circle C centered at (0,-dz/2) and intersects it at (-dz*np.sin(theta), dz/2-dz*(1-np.cos(theta))) and is directed by the vector (cos(theta), sin(theta)). That behaviour is equivalent to a shift normal to the perfect mirror of -dz*np.abs(-1+3*cos(theta)/2-sin(theta)/tan(2*theta)) and leads to a vertical shift of the exit beam of that quantity times sin(2*theta)/sin(theta). This script aligns the grating and the mirror in such a configuration

Parameters:

  • offset_mirror_center (bool) – If True, the center of the mirror is set above th grating center so as to measure the necessary length of the mirror. Will raise a warning since that all next optical element will be offset

  • grating (pyoptix.Grating or inherited) – grating instance to be aligned

  • verbose (int) – verbose level

  • mirror (pyoptix.PlaneMirror or inherited) – mirror instance of the monochromator to be aligned

  • lambda_align (float) – wavelength in m at which to perform computation

  • condition (str) – second condition for angle computations, can be ‘cff’, ‘omega’, ‘alpha’ or ‘deviation’

  • condition_value (float or callable) – values that the condition takes. can be either a float for condition=cst or a callable that returns a value of condition for a given wavelength

  • dz (float) – Offset between incoming and outgoing beam in the monochromator in m

  • return_parameters (bool) – if True all alignment values are return by the function in a dict

Returns:

Return type:

pyoptix.classes.align_grating(grating: ~typing.Optional[~pyoptix.classes.Grating] = None, verbose: int = 0, apply_alignment: bool = True, return_parameters: bool = False, condition: str = 'cff', condition_value=<function <lambda>>, lambda_align: float = 1e-09, order: int = 1, line_density: float = 450000.0)¶

Method for aligning a grating using a relation between alpha and beta grazing angles such as their sum is known (known deviation), their difference is known (known omega), alpha is known (known incidence) or in the constant focal position condition (known cff=sin(beta)/sin(alpha)).

Parameters:

  • order (int) – diffraction order on which the grating is aligned. Ignored if grating is not None.

  • line_density (float) – line density of the grating at its center. Ignored if grating is not None

  • grating (pyoptix.Grating or inherited) – grating instance to be aligned

  • verbose (int) – verbose level

  • apply_alignment (bool) – if True, grating is set to the position, otherwise value are computed but not set

  • return_parameters (bool) – if True all alignment values are return by the function in a dict

  • condition (str) – second condition for angle computations, can be ‘cff’, ‘omega’, ‘alpha’ or ‘deviation’

  • condition_value (float or callable) – values that the condition takes. can be either a float for condition=cst or a callable that returns a value of condition for a given wavelength

  • lambda_align (float) – wavelength in m at which to perform computation

Returns:

None or dictionnary containing computed values

Return type:

NoneType or dict

pyoptix.classes.set_backend(bckend='bokeh')¶

Toggles between a bokeh backend for the spot diagrams and a plotly one (preferred) :param bckend: backend to be chosen can be ‘bokeh’ or ‘plotly’ :type bckend: str

PyOptiX optimizers¶

pyoptix.optimize.custom_optimizer(beamline, screen, wavelengths, oes, attributes, dimension='y', nrays=None, method='Nelder-Mead', show_progress=False, tol=0.001, options=None, move_screen=False, norm=2, special_align=<function <lambda>>, verbose=1)¶

Optimize the optical system based on the figure of merit (FOM) using the specified optimization method.

Parameters:

  • beamline (pyoptix.Beamline) – Beamline object containing the optical elements and their properties

  • screen (pyoptix.OpticalElement) – Screen object containing the position and orientation of the screen in the beamline

  • wavelengths (float or list of floats) – Wavelengths to be used in the optimization

  • oes (object or list of objects) – Optical element(s) to be optimized, length has to match the number of attibutes.

  • attributes (str or list of str) – Attribute(s) of the optical element(s) to be optimized, length has to match the number or optical elements

  • dimension (str, optional) – Dimension of the screen diagram to be optimized (default is “y”)

  • nrays (int, optional) – Number of rays used to generate the diagram (default is None)

  • method (str, optional) – Optimization method to be used (default is “Nelder-Mead”)

  • show_progress (bool, optional) – If True, print the current value of the FOM during optimization (default is False)

  • tol (float, optional) – Tolerance for termination (default is 1e-3)

  • options (dict, optional) – Options for the optimization method (default is None)

  • move_screen (bool, optional) – If True, move the screen to the focal position during optimization (default is False)

  • norm (int, optional) – Order of the norm used to calculate the FOM (default is 2)

  • special_align (callable, optional) – function to be called before running simulation, can be used for alignment

  • verbose (int, optional) – If 1, print the optimized values of the attributes (default is 1)

Returns:

Optimized value of the first attribute of the first optical element

Return type:

float

Raises:

RuntimeError – If the optimization fails to converge to a minimum

Notes

The function uses the figure of merit (FOM) defined as the norm of the standard deviations of the screen diagrams for the specified wavelengths. The optimization method minimizes the FOM with respect to the specified attribute(s) of the optical element(s).

pyoptix.optimize.find_focus(beamline, screen, wavelength, dimension='y', nrays=None, method='Nelder-Mead', show_progress=False, tol=0.001, options=None, adjust_distance=True, verbose=1)¶

Function to be called for minimizing a focused spot diagram placed at “screen” by varying it distance to the previous oe in the “beamline” beamline. One can either try to focus horizontally, vertically or in both dimension by specifying the “dimension” parameter with respectively “x”, “y” or “xy”. Number of rays for the computation can be specified or the nrays parameter of the beamline source will be used. Minimization method can be specified, see scipy.optimize.minimize documentation for available algorithms. If adjust_distance is set to True, when convergence is reached, the distance between screen and previous OE is set to the calculated optimal value.

Parameters:

  • beamline (pyoptix.Beamline) – Beamline along which to propagate rays

  • screen (any class inheriting pyoptix.OpticalElement) – recording surface where beam must be focused

  • wavelength (float) – wavelength at which beamline must be aligned in m.

  • dimension (str) – dimension along which focusing is desired. Must be “x”, “y” or “xy”

  • nrays (int) – Number of rays to propagate

  • method (str) – Method to be used for minimisation, default “Nedler-Mead”

  • show_progress (bool) – If True, each iteration will print the current variable value and value of the function to be minimized

  • tol (float) – Tolerance for the optimizer, See scipy.optimize.minimize documentation

  • options (dict) – Method-specific options, see scipy.optimize.minimize for details

  • adjust_distance (bool) – if True, sets the screen at the optimal distance

  • verbose (int) – Verbose level control. 0 is silent

Returns:

Optimal distance from the screen to get focus in given dimension

Return type:

float

Raises:

RuntimeError – if distance has no effect or minimum cannot be reached with asked tolerance

pyoptix.optimize.focus(beamline, variable_oe, variable, wavelength, screen, dimension='y', nrays=None, method='Nelder-Mead', show_progress=False, tol=0.001, options=None, verbose=1)¶

Function to be called for minimizing a focused spot diagram placed at “screen” by varying the parameter “variable” of the optical element “variable_oe” of the “beamline” beamline. Each iteration is realigned at wavelength “wavelength”. One can either try to focus horizontally, vertically or in both dimension by specifying the “dimension” parameter with respectively “x”, “y” or “xy”. Number of rays for the computation can be specified or the nrays parameter of the beamline source will be used. Minimization method can be specified, see scipy.optimize.minimize documentation for available algorithms.

Parameters:

  • beamline (pyoptix.Beamline) – Beamline along which to propagate rays

  • variable_oe (any class inheriting pyoptix.OpticalElement) – Optical element whose parameter must be varied

  • variable (str) – name of the parameter to be varied

  • wavelength (float) – wavelength at which beamline must be aligned in m.

  • screen (any class inheriting pyoptix.OpticalElement) – recording surface where beam must be focused

  • dimension (str) – dimension along which focusing is desired. Must be “x”, “y” or “xy”

  • nrays (int) – Number of rays to propagate

  • method (str) – Method to be used for minimisation, default “Nedler-Mead”

  • show_progress (bool) – If True, each iteration will print the current variable value and value of the function to be minimized

  • tol (float) – Tolerance for the optimizer, See scipy.optimize.minimize documentation

  • options (dict) – Method-specific options, see scipy.optimize.minimize for details

  • verbose (int) – Verbose level control. 0 is silent

Returns:

optimal value of the variable to achieve focusing

Return type:

float

Raises:

RuntimeError – if variable has no effect or minimum cannot be reached with asked tolerance

pyoptix.optimize.slider_optimizer(variable_oe=None, variable='', variable_bounds=(), variable_step=0.1, screen=None, wavelength=6e-09, nrays=None, display='yyp', light_spd=False)¶

Prints out the spot diagram kind asked in display on the surface of ‘screen’ and a slider object which when moved will update the spot diagram. The slider sets the value of the variable ‘variable’ of the optical element ‘variable_oe’ between ‘variable_bounds’ by increment of ‘variable_step’. All propagated rays are at wavelength ‘wavelength’.

Parameters:

  • variable_oe (any class inheriting pyoptix.OpticalElement) – Optical element whose parameter must be varied

  • variable (str) – name of the parameter to be varied

  • wavelength (float) – wavelength at which beamline must be aligned in m.

  • nrays (int) – Number of rays to propagate

  • screen (any class inheriting pyoptix.OpticalElement) – recording surface where beam must be focused

  • variable_bounds (tuple fo float) – Bounds of the variable and thus the slider

  • variable_step (float) – Minimum increment for the slider

  • display (str) – Indicates which representation is to be shown, can be “xy”, “xxp” or “yyp”

  • light_spd (bool) – set to True for quick monochromatic rendering of the scatter plot

Returns:

None

Return type:

NoneType

PyOptiX vizualisations¶

These functions are those called by OpticalElement.show_diagram, they are given here in case a user would want to plot something unforseen.

pyoptix.ui_objects.config_forge(beamline, lambda_align, lambda_radiate, names=None)¶

Creates interactive Jupyterlab widgets that sets up the simulation using alignment parameters and entropy from beamline.chains names so that a user friendly selection can be made. Since the meaning of the names of the configuration are user dependent, the names can be given in argument. For example, if configuration are names in a pattern “<source name>_<grating name>_<endstation name>”, names should be [“source name”,”grating”,”endstation”], otherwise widget will be names “Configuration element 1” and so on.

Use example :

>> display(config_forge(beamline=Hermes, lambda_align=lambda_align, lambda_radiate=lambda_radiate,
    names=["Ondulator","End station","Grating"]))
Parameters:

  • beamline (pyoptix.classes.Beamline) – beamline to be configured

  • lambda_align (float) – wavelength at which to align the optical elements in m

  • lambda_radiate (float) – wavelength to radiate from source in m

  • names (list) – list of names indexing beamline.chains names, see above.

Returns:

layout containing widgets to display

Return type:

ipywidgets.VBox

pyoptix.ui_objects.display_parameter_sheet(oe)¶

Displays the parameters of an optical element in a table jupyterlab widget

Parameters:

oe (pyoptix.OpticalElement or inherited) – optical element the parameters of which to display

Returns:

table widget

Return type:

ipysheet.sheet

pyoptix.ui_objects.display_progress_bar(max_count)¶

Displays and a progressbar jupyterlab widget for long calculations. To update, add 1 to the returned object.value.

Parameters:

max_count (int) – maximum expected value for progressbar

Returns:

progress bar widget

Return type:

ipywidgets.IntProgress

pyoptix.ui_objects.format_prefix(value, precision=2, unit='m')¶

Formats a numerical value with an appropriate SI prefix.

Args: - value: A float representing the numerical value to be formatted. - precision: An integer representing the number of decimal places to include in the formatted value (default: 2). - unit: A string representing the unit of measurement to be appended to the formatted value (default: “m”).

Returns: - A string representing the formatted value with the appropriate SI prefix and unit.

Raises: - ValueError: If the exponent is out of range of the available prefixes.

pyoptix.ui_objects.generate_widget_for_callable_argument(callable_func)¶

Generate JupyterLab widgets to set the argument of a callable function.

Parameters:

callable_func (callable) – The function for which you want to create widgets.

Returns:

A VBox widget containing input widgets for the callable’s arguments.

Return type:

widgets.VBox

pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_beamline_normals(beamline, enlarge_normals=True, orthonormal=True)¶

Plots the normal to each optical element surface along the beamline :param orthonormal: makes the axes orthonormal (angles appear as in reality, but small offsets are hard to see) :type orthonormal: bool :param enlarge_normals: multiply the normals by a big factor to make them more visible :type enlarge_normals: bool :param beamline: Aligned beamline the optical element of which to plot :type beamline: pyoptix.Beamline :return: None :rtype: NoneType

pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_polynomial_surface(coeffs, xy_limits, legendre=False, mesh=100, probe_stat=0.002)¶

Plots a 3D surface of a polynomial described by its coefficients on a specified XY plane.

Parameters:

  • coeffs (list or array-like) – Coefficients of the polynomial in descending order of degree.

  • xy_limits (list or array-like) – A list or array of length 4 that specifies the limits of the surface on the XY plane. The first and second elements correspond to the minimum and maximum values of x, respectively, while the third and fourth elements correspond to the minimum and maximum values of y, respectively.

  • probe_stat (float) – A size over which to compute the statistical form and slope errors as with an optical profiler

  • mesh (int) – number of sampling points over the surface size for each axis

  • legendre (bool) – if True the coefficients are applied to the legendre serie of polynomials, if False over the natural polynomials

Return type:

plotly.graph_objects.Figure

Example

>>> coeffs = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
>>> xy_limits = [-5, 5, -10, 10]
>>> fig = plot_polynomial_surface(coeffs, xy_limits)
>>> fig.show()
pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd(columndatasource, x_key='x', y_key='y', oe_name='', **kwargs)¶

Wrapper function for the PyOptix object of the scatter_plot_2d function. Data is expected as first parameter in a pandas.Dataframe, the column names must contain X_key and y_key.

Parameters:

  • columndatasource (bokeh.models.ColumnDataSource) – ColumnDataSource to be plotted with keys given by xkey and ykey

  • x_key (str) – name of the Dataframe column containing the X value

  • y_key (str) – name of the Dataframe column containing the Y value

  • kwargs – See scatter_plot_2d doc for additional parameters

  • oe_name (str) – Name of the optical element where the diagram is captured

Returns:

layout of the plot to be used as parameter of bokeh.plotting.show

Return type:

bokeh.models.layouts.LayoutDOM

pyoptix.ui_objects.plot_spd_plotly(df, x_key='x', y_key='y', oe_name='', show_map=False, light_plot=False, orthonorm=False, save_in_file='', return_fwhm=False, **kwargs)¶

Wrapper function for the PyOptix object of the scatter_plot_2d function. Data is expected as first parameter in a pandas.Dataframe, the column names must contain X_key and y_key.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame or pyoptix.OpticalElement) – DataFrame to be plotted with keys given by xkey and ykey or OpticalElement the diagram of which to plot

  • light_plot (bool) – Does not color scatter points for quick plot

  • orthonorm (bool) – Sets X range = Y range so as to have a real life spot shape

  • save_in_file (str) – Name of the file to save the layout to as a png. Default = “”, which means not saving to file

  • return_fwhm (bool) – If True, returns the Full Width at Half Maximum of the spot is both dimensions as well as the plot layout

  • show_map (bool) – Plot an hexagonal map instead of scatter plot

  • x_key (str) – name of the Dataframe column containing the X value

  • y_key (str) – name of the Dataframe column containing the Y value

  • kwargs – See scatter_plot_2d doc for additional parameters

  • oe_name (str) – Name of the optical element where the diagram is captured

Returns:

layout of the plot to be used as parameter of bokeh.plotting.show

Return type:

bokeh.models.layouts.LayoutDOM

pyoptix.ui_objects.scatter_plot_2d(cds, xkey, ykey, title='', x_unit='', y_unit='', show_map=False, light_plot=False, orthonorm=False, radius=5, x_label='', y_label='', save_in_file='', return_fwhm=False, color_scale='density')¶

Function that draws a scatter plot using bokeh. Scatter points are colored as a function of local density so as to better grip spot shape when density gets high.

Parameters:

  • cds (bokeh.models.ColumnDataSource) – ColumnDataSource to be plotted with keys given by xkey and ykey

  • xkey (numpy.ndarray) – X data coordinate

  • ykey (numpy.ndarray) – Y data coordinate

  • title (str) – Title of the plot

  • x_unit (str) – Unit of the X coordinate

  • y_unit (str) – Unit of the Y coordinate

  • show_map (bool) – Plot an hexagonal map instead of scatter plot

  • light_plot (bool) – Does not color scatter points for quick plot

  • orthonorm (bool) – Sets X range = Y range so as to have a real life spot shape

  • radius (float) – Radius of scatter point, default = 5

  • x_label (str) – Label of the X coordinate

  • y_label (str) – Label of the y coordinate

  • save_in_file (str) – Name of the file to save the layout to as a png. Default = “”, which means not saving to file

  • return_fwhm (bool) – If True, returns the Full Width at Half Maximum of the spot is both dimensions as well as the plot layout

  • color_scale (str) – Value to color the points with, default = “density”, acceptable values : any spot diagram column name or “density”

Returns:

layout of the plot to be used as parameter of bokeh.plotting.show or tuple (layout, FWHMs)

Return type:

bokeh.models.layouts.LayoutDOM or (LayoutDOM, (float, float))

PyOptiX tolerancing¶

These functions aim at providing easy tolerancing of beamline using Monte-Carlo generated version of a beamline.

pyoptix.tolerancing.apply_tolerance_data(beamline, tolerance_data)¶

Takes the links to the display objects generated by display_tolerance_data and set the values of every parameter of every optic in beamline active chain to the values in the table objects

Parameters:

  • beamline (pyoptix.Beamline) – beamline to be changed

  • tolerance_data (list) – links to the parameters of every optics in beamline active chain as ipysheet.sheet

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

pyoptix.tolerancing.display_tolerance_data(beamline, oe_list=None)¶

Displays the parameters of every optics in beamline active chain in a editable format

Parameters:

  • beamline (pyoptix.Beamline) – beamline to analyze

  • oe_list (list) – list of optical element to tolerance. If None, all OE are diplayed

Returns:

list of ipysheet.sheet objects containing the links to the tables displayed

Return type:

list

pyoptix.tolerancing.generate_MC_beamline(beamline, distribution='gauss')¶

Changes the values of every optics parameter which has non [0,0] bounds randomly using a given distribution, “extreme” distribution sets the value of parameter either to the min or max value of its bounds

Note: a gauss distribution ca lead to value outside the bounds interval as the bounds are defined as 2*sigma

Note 2: the function leaves the beamline changed.

Parameters:

  • beamline (pyoptix.Beamline) – beamline to be changed

  • distribution (str) – random distribution for the new values, can be “uniform”, “extreme” or “gauss”

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

pyoptix.tolerancing.sensitivity_analysis(beamline, N_stat=100, N_rays=1000, distribution='uniform', quality=<function <lambda>>, tolerance_data=None, compensator=None, wavelength=2e-08)¶

Computes and runs N_stat version of the beamline each changed randomly using either the existing parameters of the beamline optics either tolerance_data as described in apply_tolerance_data. each version is run with N_rays rays and qualifed by calling the quality function which take beamline as an argument and returns either a numerical value or an iterable of numerical values. The result is a statistical description of the values return by the quality function.

Parameters:

  • beamline (pyoptix.Beamline) – beamline to be analyzed

  • N_stat (int) – number of beamlines to compute

  • N_rays (int) – number of rays to propagate for each beamline

  • distribution (str) – distribution of the varied parameters, see generate_MC_beamline

  • quality (callable) – function returning numerical values to examine

  • tolerance_data (list) – if supplied, sets the optical parameters to these data. See apply_tolerance_data

  • compensator (callable) – function returning None to be called after each beamline generation to compensate changes. Usually an optimization function. Takes no parameter.

  • wavelength (float) – Wavelength in m at which the beamline is aligned and radiated

Returns:

statistical analysis of the values returned by quality function

Return type:

scipy.describe

PyOptiX MCPL interface¶

This module provides read write functions for MonteCarloParticleList input/output. Using methods from pyoptix.classes should be used instead of direct call to these functions.

Python module for accessing MCPL files.

The MCPL (Monte Carlo Particle Lists) format is thoroughly documented on the project homepage, from where it is also possible to download the entire MCPL distribution:

https://mctools.github.io/mcpl/

Specifically, more documentation about how to use the present python module to access MCPL files can be found at:

https://mctools.github.io/mcpl/usage_python/

This file can freely used as per the terms in the LICENSE file distributed with MCPL, also available at https://github.com/mctools/mcpl/blob/master/LICENSE .

A substantial effort went into developing MCPL. If you use it for your work, we would appreciate it if you would use the following reference in your work:

T. Kittelmann, et al., Monte Carlo Particle Lists: MCPL, Computer Physics Communications 218, 17-42 (2017), https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cpc.2017.04.012

mcpl.py written by Thomas Kittelmann, 2017-2019. The work was supported by the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No 676548 (the BrightnESS project)

mcpl.py edited to fit pyoptix interface requirement by David Dennetiere 2022

exception pyoptix.mcpl.MCPLError¶

Common exception class for all exceptions raised by module

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

class pyoptix.mcpl.MCPLFile(filename, blocklength=10000, raw_strings=False)¶

Python-only class for reading MCPL files, using numpy and internal caches to ensure good efficiency. File access is read-only, and the particles can only be read in consecutive and forward order, providing either single particles or blocks of particles as requested.

__init__(filename, blocklength=10000, raw_strings=False)¶

Open indicated mcpl file, which can either be uncompressed (.mcpl) or compressed (.mcpl.gz). The blocklength parameter can be used to control the number of particles read by each call to read_block(). The parameter raw_strings has no effect in python2. In python3, it will prevent utf-8 decoding of string data loaded from the file.

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

property blob_storage_order¶

In-file storage order of binary blobs (as list of keys).

property blobs¶

Dictionary of custom binary blobs (byte-arrays) embedded in the file header. Each such blob is associated with a key, which is also the key in the dictionary

property blocklength¶

Number of particles read by each call to read_block()

property comments¶

List of custom comments (strings) embedded in the file header

dump_hdr()¶

Dump file header to stdout (using a format identical to the one from the compiled mcpltool)

dump_particles(limit=10, skip=0)¶

Dump a list of particles to stdout (using a format identical to the one from the compiled mcpltool). The limit and skip parameters can be used to respectively limit the number of particles printed and to skip past particles at the head of the file. Use limit=0 to disable the limit.

property endianness¶

Endianness of numbers in file

property headersize¶

Uncompressed size of the file header [bytes]

property nparticles¶

Number of particles in file

property opt_polarisation¶

Whether or not polarisation info is enabled in file

property opt_singleprec¶

Whether or not floating point numbers in particle data are stored in single-precision (32bit) rather than double-precision (64bit)

property opt_universalpdgcode¶

Global PDG code for all particles in file (a value of 0 means that PDG codes are stored per-particle)

property opt_universalweight¶

Global weight for all particles in file (a value of 0.0 means that weights are stored per-particle)

property opt_userflags¶

Whether or not userflags are enabled in file

property particle_blocks¶

Use to iterate over all particles in file, returning a block of particles each time for efficiency:

for p in thefile.particle_blocks:

print p.x,p.y,p.z #NB: the “values” here are actually arrays

property particles¶

Use to iterate over all particles in file:

for p in thefile.particles:

print p.x,p.y,p.z

property particlesize¶

Uncompressed per-particle storage size in file [bytes]

read()¶

Read and return next particle in file (None when EOF) as a particle object, with particle state information available on fields as seen in the following example:

p = mcplfile.read()
if p is not None:
     print p.x,p.y,p.z
     print p.ux,p.uy,p.uz
     print p.polx,p.poly,p.polz
     print p.ekin,p.time,p.weight,p.userflags

See also the particles property for an iterator-based access to particles. Furthermore, note that the read_blocks() function and the particle_blocks property provides block-based access, which can improve performance dramatically.

read_block()¶

Read and return next block of particles (None when EOF). Similar to read(), but returned “particle” object actually represents a whole block of particles, and the fields on it are thus (numpy) arrays of numbers rather than single numbers. See also the particle_blocks property for an iterator-based access to blocks.

rewind()¶

Rewind file, causing next calls to read() and read_blocks() to start again at the beginning of the file.

skip_forward(n)¶

skip n positions forward in file. (returns False when there is no particle at the new position, otherwise True)

property sourcename¶

Name of application that wrote the MCPL file

property version¶

MCPL format version of the file

class pyoptix.mcpl.MCPLParticle(block, idx)¶

Object representing a single particle

__init__(block, idx)¶

For internal use only - users should not normally create MCPLParticle objects themselves

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

property direction¶

normalised momentum direction as 3-dimensional array

property ekin¶

kinetic energy [MeV]

property file_index¶

Particle position in file (counting from 0)

property pdgcode¶

MC particle number from the Particle Data Group (2112=neutron, 22=gamma, …)

property polarisation¶

polarisation vector as 3-dimensional array

property polx¶

x-coordinate of polarisation vector

property poly¶

y-coordinate of polarisation vector

property polz¶

z-coordinate of polarisation vector

property position¶

position as 3-dimensional array [cm]

property time¶

time-stamp [millisecond]

property userflags¶

custom per-particle flags

property ux¶

x-coordinate of normalised momentum direction

property uy¶

y-coordinate of normalised momentum direction

property uz¶

z-coordinate of normalised momentum direction

property weight¶

weight or intensity

property x¶

x-coordinate of position [cm]

property y¶

y-coordinate of position [cm]

property z¶

z-coordinate of position [cm]

class pyoptix.mcpl.MCPLParticleBlock(opt_polarisation, opt_userflags, opt_globalw, opt_globalpdg, fmtversion)¶

Object representing a block of particle. Fields are arrays rather than single numbers, but otherwise have the same meaning as on the MCPLParticle class.

__getitem__(ipos)¶

Access single particle in block by local position in block (not global position in file)

__init__(opt_polarisation, opt_userflags, opt_globalw, opt_globalpdg, fmtversion)¶

For internal use only - users should not normally create MCPLParticle objects themselves

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

property file_offset¶

Particle position in file of first particle in block (counting from 0)

get_by_global(ipos)¶

Access single particle in block by global position in file

property particles¶

Use to iterate over all particles in block:

for p in theblock.particles:

print p.x,p.y,p.z

class pyoptix.mcpl.PyOptixMCPLReader(filename, header=True, particles=False, limit=10, skip=0, verbose=1, **kwargs)¶

Reader of MCPL files for PyOptiX

Use get_diagram to generate a pyoptix Diagram usable as a source for propagation in the code

__init__(filename, header=True, particles=False, limit=10, skip=0, verbose=1, **kwargs)¶

Opens the MCPL file filename and outputs some of it content if verbose is not 0.

Parameters:

  • filename (str) – name of the file to be opened

  • header (bool) – if verbose is > 0, prints file header

  • particles (bool) – if verbose is > 0, prints ‘limit’ particles

  • limit (int) – number of particles to be printed if verbose is > 0 and particles is True

  • skip (int) – number of particles to be skipped before printing if verbose is > 0 and particles is True

  • verbose (int) – verbose level at opening file

  • kwargs (dict) – additional keyword to pass to mcpl.dump_file

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

get_diagram(show_first_rays=False, ndim=5)¶

Extracts photons (gamma) from MCPL files and returns a Diagram structure for PyOptiX :return: diagram :rtype: optix.Diagram

plot_diagram(display='all', light_xy=False, map_xy=False, light_xxp=False, light_yyp=False, show_spd=True, **kwargs)¶

Plots the photon particles stored in the MCPL file :return: None :rtype: Nonetype

class pyoptix.mcpl.PyOptixMCPLWriter(filename)¶

Writer of MCPL files for PyOptiX

Use dump_diagram to register a pyoptix Diagram usable as MCPL file, add_comment if need be then write_to_file

__init__(filename)¶
__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

add_comment(comment)¶

Adds a comment line to be written in the MCPL file.

Parameters:

comment (str) – comment to be added

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

dump_diagram(diagram)¶

Computes the bytesize per particle and adds particles from diagram to the particle list to be written

Parameters:

diagram (PyOptiX.classes.Diagram) – PyOptiX Diagram to be recorded

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

write_to_file()¶

Writes the MCPL file at adress provided in contructor

Returns:

None

Return type:

Nonetype

pyoptix.mcpl.app_pymcpltool(argv=None)¶

Implements a python equivalent of the compiled MCPL tool. If no argv list is passed in, sys.argv will be used. In case of errors, MCPLError exceptions are raised.

pyoptix.mcpl.collect_stats(mcplfile, stats='all', bin_data=True)¶

Efficiently collect statistics from an entire file (or part of file, if limit or skip parameters are set). Returns dictionary with stat names as key and the collected statistics as values.

pyoptix.mcpl.convert2ascii(mcplfile, outfile)¶

Read particle contents of mcplfile and write into outfile using a simple ASCII-based format

pyoptix.mcpl.dump_file(filename, header=True, particles=True, limit=10, skip=0, **kwargs)¶

Python equivalent of mcpl_dump(..) function from mcpl.h, which can be used to dump both header and particle contents of a file to stdout.

pyoptix.mcpl.dump_stats(stats)¶

Format and print provided statistics object to stdout. The stats object is assumed to have been created by a call to collect_stats()

pyoptix.mcpl.main()¶

This function simply calls app_pymcpltool(), but any raised MCPLError exception will be caught and transformed into a corresponding error message followed by a call to sys.exit(1). Invoking the mcpl.py module as a script (for instance with “python -m”) will result in a call to this function.

pyoptix.mcpl.plot_stats(stats, pdf=False, set_backend=None)¶

Produce plots of provided statistics object with matplotlib. The pdf parameter can be set to a filename and if so, the plots will be produced in that newly created PDF file, rather than being shown interactively. The set_backend parameter can be used to select a matplotlib backend. The stats object is assumed to have been created by a call to collect_stats().
